content.description:
Straight forward climbing on edges leads to a dicey top out.

Pretty uniform flat edges up the wall to a jug just below the lip. This jug will allow you to contemplate the sloping, nearly hold less top out. There is a good hold back there (you may want to check this out before heading up the problem) but you will likely have to pull off of some pretty small nipples to get to it.
content.protection: Pads and spotter, there are a couple of low boulders in the landing area but a good spot should have no problem steering you between them.
content.location: This problem in just left of center on the nice clean overhang on the right side of the boulder as you approach from the main trail.

content.description: Legacy of the Kid is the prize line on this bloc with powerful and complex moves. Start sitting with a good left incut and a right hand pinch in the low horizontal. Move up through sculpted rails, pockets (both large and small), and a few crimpers to a not casual top out.
content.protection: Several pads. The problem is relatively tall and steep, so you either need a spotter to move pads or enough to cover the mostly flat landing.
content.location:
This is on the tall, steep, southeast face of the boulder. It shares the start (first three moves) with

El Diablo

on a low, large, horizontal crack/rail then branches right and directly up.

content.description:
Start on the far left of the

LOTK

face, traverse rightwards on nice calcified edges, and finish up the

Unknown V2

in center.

Start right of

Legacy of the Kid

with huecos, and climb into this line at the three finger pocket via a slot pinch and bad undercling.
content.location:
It starts right of

Legacy of the Kid

.

content.description:
Unique slopy and pebbly pinches on a gently overhung face make this problem intriguing.

Start from a sit at the base of a low roof and on an arete. Move up through the roof onto the face and the sloping pinches. Figure out how to best use these holds to get to the right hand gaston and make a long reach up for a horizontal and then head left to the arete and a high but casual top out.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, the landing is pretty good.
content.location: When you approach the boulder from the trail, head left along the lest steep wall until you come to the low overhang at far end of the boulder. Last Tango starts at the base of the overhang but climbs the less steep wall.

content.description:
Use the same start as the V5, but move right into

Backyard Playground

, and top out.
content.location: It is next to the V2 in the cave.

content.description:
Start off the low jug between some rocks and move up to a rail. Next make a big and committing move to the next hold, a good spot for your head and toe cam might prove useful. Match up and make another long move up and right to better holds and finally into the top of the V2 and its thin top out.

Would get 3 stars if not for the fact that this is a variation to the best looking line on the boulder.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. There are rocks in the landing at the start and the finish of this problem.
content.location: This problem is on the the nice clean overhang. Starting from a low sit on the right side on a big rounded and somewhat positive two handed hold.

content.description:
A steep and low problem, if you are adverse to getting off the ground this is for you, high dab potential.

Start from a low sit on the arete between the overhang and the less steep wall that Last Tango in Durango climbs, in the same place as that problem. Move out the corner and arete in the roof to a big move getting around the lip. A fun mantle onto the slab finishes things off.
content.protection: Pad and spotter, though a spotter could possibly get in the way more than help, mainly to move the pad under the climber.
content.location: When approaching the boulder from the trail, head left along the wall until you come to the low overhang at the end. Sit down and start.
